contents: Intro; Acknowledgments; Contents; Notes on Contributors; List of Figures; List of Pictures; List of Tables; Chapter 1: Introduction; References; Chapter 2: The Relevance of Real Estate in Solving Climate Change; Chapter 3: Evolutions in Sustainability and Sustainable Real Estate; 1 Introduction; 2 The Rise of Sustainable Development; 3 Sustainability and Real Estate; 3.1 Real Estate and the Environment; 3.2 Real Estate and the Economy; 3.3 Real Estate and Society; 4 Toward Sustainable Real Estate; 4.1 Current Trends; 4.2 Criticism of Current Trends.

4.3 The Role of Tenants, Investors, Governments and Financial Institutions4.4 Future Directions in Sustainable Real Estate; 5 Conclusion: Mapping the Sustainable Real Estate System; References; Part I: Regulatory Approaches; Chapter 4: Public Regulatory Trends in Sustainable Real Estate; 1 Introduction; 2 Strategic Planning, Development Controls and Incentives; 2.1 Forward Planning Strategies; 2.1.1 Comprehensive Planning; 2.2 Development Controls; 2.2.1 Prescriptive Zoning; 2.2.2 Performance-Based Zoning; 2.2.3 Prescriptive Versus Performance-Based Building Codes.

2.3 Development Incentives3 Mandatory Disclosure and Integrated Reporting; 4 Public Procurement Standards; 5 Discussion and Recommendations; 5.1 Application of the UN SDGs to Improve Sustainability Outcomes in Strategic Planning; 5.2 Increasing the Impact of Mandatory Disclosure and Integrated Reporting Requirements; 5.3 Incentives that More Accurately Reflect the Value-Add of Sustainable Development; References; Chapter 5: A Policy Framework for Sustainable Real Estate in the European Union; 1 Introduction; 2 The European Union Walks the Talk on Sustainable Real Estate.

2.1 A Common Framework of Standards and Practices2.1.1 Member States to Save 1.5% Primary Energy and Renovate 3% of Public Buildings; 2.1.2 European Standards and Labels for Products; 2.1.3 Set National Requirements that Respect the Principle of Cost Optimality in Construction and Renovation; 2.1.4 Construct Only Nearly Zero-Energy Building by 2021; 2.1.5 Deliver Energy Performance Certificates (EPCs) to Buildings; 2.1.6 Ensure Improved Connectivity in New Constructions; 2.2 The EU Budget to Reduce Market Barriers; 2.2.1 De-Risking Private Investments in Renovation; Structural Funds.

Juncker PlanELENA Fund, Technical Assistance for Municipalities; 2.2.2 Financing Innovation to Tackle Market Barriers; Setting a European Exchange Platform to Share Best Practices; Support the Uptake of Promising Low-Cost Renovation Techniques; Provide European-Wide Information on Building Stocks, Renovation and Construction Rates and Policies; 3 Diversity in National Approaches; 3.1 Countries Mapping; 3.2 Major Challenges to Sustainable Real Estate; 3.2.1 Financing the Renovation; Energies POSIT'IF (Ile-de-France, France); Picardie Pass Renovation (Picardie, France); Saerbeck (Germany).
